newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.African plans partial airports sale by March '98.
newsitem.headline: S.African plans partial airports sale by March '98.

text.p: The South African government expects to complete the partial privatisation of the state-owned Airports Company by March 1998, Transport Minister Mac Maharaj said on Monday.

The plan is to sell up to 49 percent of the company, which operates Johannesburg, Cape Town and Durban international airports and six regional airports. The aim was to float the balance on the stock exchange within two years.
Bankers bidding to advise the government on the sale had valued to total concern at around 2.5 billion rand, Maharaj said.
Maharaj said 20 percent of the company would be sold to a foreign strategic equity partner which would form a consortium with local black business groups to take up to 49 percent in total.

There had been eight to 10 strong expressions of interest in acquiring a stake in the Airports Co from firms around the world, he added. Inquiries has come from BAA PLc, the Malaysia Aiports Authority and Schiphol, Vienna and Frankfurt aiports, among others.
"We expect that the process will be completed by March 1998 and then it is government's intention to list the other 51 percent," Marahaj said.
The planned listing would be discussed with labour groups, he added.
